commentBody: Wow, that went quickly.
Lots of fun! Although it went by awfully fast. I loved some of the juxtapositions--TRAGIC HERO next to ONION RINGS, PIGEONHOLE under AS EXPECTED, etc.
What's in a name? A smashing back to back Shakespeare / Disney character reference, that's what. So much in this puzzle to admire, but it went by much too fast.

A bright and breezy puzzle that went down as smoothly as a black and white milkshake.  There were lots of witty clues, especially those for ONIONRINGS and REPORTCARD. And as an old English major I loved the plethora of Shakespeare references.  I do question though whether Gatsby qualifies as a true tragic hero.

A total pleasure. Well 
done with no obscure proper nouns or rap references. The cluing for the ubiquitous oreo was interesting. How many different ways has oreo been clued, I wonder??
Happiness is a Robyn Weintraub Friday puzzle.  With the added bonus of constructor comments.

"Look at all these capacitors and inductors!"
"How can I resist?"

(That one does well on the comedy circuit.)
I had a very long and tiring day, but seeing Robyn’s name on this one as I flopped into bed cheered me right up. If you disliked this crossword, you should probably stop doing them.

Fun puzzle!
I couldn’t bring it up in the app on my phone or iPad. Did anyone else run into this problem?

I didn't know a few things:  Penang, Levi, suit, sail.  I was still happy with it, not having to google anything to get the answers.  It's rare to have that much consistency: nothing too hard, and nothing too easy, for a smooth solve.

Very nice cluing. 

Believe it or not there are TWO Malaysian words in this puzzle. Penang of course, and amok, which may mean unchecked in English, but in it's original language still means on a wild rampage.

Unrelated, but in Cambodia amok is a fish curry.

I am definitely part of a Seal team, so I'm singing with him "I have been waiting, waiting for you" ‐ https://youtu.be/tpv36VoqYzU?si=Fbh49NrLbRu7Zo-R Yes, I have been waiting for you, Robyn Weintraub...for that Friday puzzle you always sprinkle with magic, and the way it flows (not because it's easy, but because of that je ne sais quoi that pulls me in and doesn't let go.) The entries wrote themselves in, and I could just sit back and savor the fill, enjoying every second. Thank you for a perfect start to the weekend, Ms. Weintraub. Your REPORT CARD says A+!
Puzzle isn’t showing up in App. First time that’s happened in over 2 years of solving. Major bummer.
Ooh I loved this one

Well, HOWCANIRESIST letting you know that this was my fasted Friday by a fair bit. I'm as surprised as you are. I'm not a speed solver. (I tanked Connections today, which is super rare for me, so this was a good EGO boost.) 

Anyhow, it was also bright and fun and I was RIVETed by it.  The long entries came pretty easily but each one sparked a little joy in me. I did briefly have WINBYAhair at 27D but it resolved itself. I feel like I haven't heard WINBYANOSE before, but it honestly makes loads of sense, so I'm sure it's very common and just doesn't register for me.

Loved the back-to-back Disney/Shakespeare entries. ONIONRINGS (yum!) gave me a great chuckle, as did 25A HALF, the F of which was my last fill. Really good! The "apparently" in the clue for RAVEN 38A was also really fun. 

Anyhow, YOUGETTHEIDEA, I liked it! 

But lastly, was it just last week or so that I was so excited to have my full first name in the puzzle? Well...  I was almost that excited because my pre-marriage name came so close to showing up today! Just have to take off three letters at the end and add one in their place. 

While I haven't done my ancestry background, it is believed with some measure of likelihood that the name as seen in the puzzle was actually my family's name before coming to the U.S. and changing it.

Heck, I'm still gonna give a little squeal of delight!! 🥳

Fun puzzle, well done.  But this continues (arguably concludes) a rather easy week overall.  I always wonder whether that is intentional or just random puzzle smattering left by editors pulling slips from the bingo tumbler.

Anyway, nice work.  So lively I almost didn't notice it was sorta themeless, Disney/Barsld stuff notwithstanding.  (For a short bit I felt sure it couldn't possibly be Ariel because her name isn't in the title.)

ONION RINGS!

HOW CAN I RESIST!?

SIPS ALES

SENDS STAR

Thanks Robyn!
I finished House of Doors (recommend) just before I started this puzzle so I got PENANG easily. It’s wild when that happens.

A quite theatrical puzzle this time, not only the two more-than-clever Disney-Bard combos, but beginning with "The Crucible" and working in "Hello Dolly," the tragic heros (I'll give you Hamlet as a one but think Gatsby qualifies as one by a nose, if that), Ilsa from Casablanca, a star for sure in the divine Ingrid Bergman, who, no crooner, won E_OT, the triple crown of acting, a "suit," the Mah Jong ladies might say, but not the Grammy. And let's not forget Ides, beware of the one in March quoth the soothsayer in Julius Caesar. Also, beware the snows of yesteryear while you're at it. 

Can a tragic hero really also be a fashionista spokesperson for the United Colors of Benetton?

"He took out a pile of shirts and began throwing them one by one before us, shirts of sheer linen and thick silk and fine flannel which lost their folds as they fell and covered the table in many-colored disarray.  While we admired, the soft rich heap mounted higher — shirts with stripes and scrolls and plaids in coral and apple green and lavender and faint orange with monograms of Indian blue. Suddenly with a strained sound Daisy bent her head into the shirts and began to cry stormily.

          “They’re such beautiful shirts,” she sobbed, her voice muffled in the thick folds.  “It makes me sad because I’ve never seen such — such beautiful shirts before.”

I love that scene. Daisy sounds so coked up, it could be right out of a Warhol film with Joe Delasandro as Gatsby and Edie Sedgwick as Daisy.
very nice puzzle. thank you. I got a bit stuck on Penang because I was sure the final letter was a "c". Oh well, gap/cap yadda yadda.
Robyn W. never disappoints (me anyway). Beautiful themeless.

I loved the clues for the Disney/Shakespeare pairing at 29A and 30A, but I'm embarrassed to say that took me just a bit longer than it should've on 29A! When I saw five letters, I immediately started thinking "Mulan" and "Moana" - characters whose actual name was the title of the movie - even though I knew there was no way either of them would be Shakespeare names. I got it once I got some of the crossing answers, and only then remembered that the titular character need not have their actual name be the title. It was a bit of a facepalm moment for me.

I also LOVED 24D. It may be my favorite question mark clue I've ever encountered in the five-plus years that I've regularly solved the NYT crossword!
Why is this not showing in iPad app?
No Friday puzzle in the iPhone app.
Enjoyed this one a lot. Loved the Disney/Shakespeare clues. Thanks!

25A. HOWCANIRE_I__

Making it to Friday after a long work week, there was only one thing on my mind, if the offer was really amazing:

HOWCANIRETIRE

TGIF!!! 😀

As to the blog, the revealed clues were not the hard clues.  On the one hand, it’s nice to know that some people think I already solved the hard ones.  But those were the simplest of the clues on the board.  

I utilize the blog to break open areas without looking at sites that will give away the entire board. 

What would have been helpful to know are:

27D
55A
33D

The puzzles really do seem like they're getting easier, and I honestly don't think it's because I'm getting better. I mean, I am getting better, but I'm also working on puzzles from 2023, and those feel much crunchier. I enjoyed some of the clues/entries in this one, but it felt to me more like a Wednesday. 

Like Deb, I loved the clue for CEMENT MIXER. 

Was confused by Timon being a titular character. Well, today this English major learned of the Shakespeare play, "Timon of Athens." From Wikipedia: 

"Timon lavishes his wealth on parasitic companions until he is poor and rejected by them. He then denounces all of mankind, and isolates himself in a cave in the wilderness."

Huh. Sounds too depressing for me right now. Unless someone responds and tells me how great it is, I don't think I'll be reading this one any time soon.
Loved this puzzle. So many good clues and felt really satisfying when they all clicked.
Yay
14A TRAGIClEad for TRAGICHERO and 37A gps instead of FOB made for some head scratching. I didn’t care for the clue for 25D at all, but found the ONIONRINGS clue sublime at 17A. Nice puzzle.

OK, it's Friday… gonna be difficult, but let's see who did this one…

Wow! it's Robyn! This is gonna be a good one! It's been a long time, and it's nice to see an old friend show up.

Of course, the NW, where I always start, turns out to be the toughest, but I managed to get started anyway, and it proved to be a typical Weintraub creation, with tricky clues, good misdirection, and along with that, everything is totally fair. Couldn't ask for more in a puzzle, but I do want more of them.

Thanks, Robyn!

I thought I'd try a themeless puzzle to see if it will be more fun than a themed one in my current blase/depressed/mysterious mindset.

Well, it was quite fun, but the areas NE and directly E defeated me and I needed lookups and reveals there.

Dolly and that Hall were both unknowns, as was CRAB for grouch. I had no idea what a sailfish is, and I only ever played mah-jong on the computer so I know no words to describe it - I'm just familiar with the visual side of it, and I never thought of it as having SUITs (btw, in Polish a suit as a card suit is "kolor" - color. Polish terminology being so different from the English is probably another reason for my confusion here).

I also never know if the Casablanca role is ILSA or eLSA. The cross did not help - I still don't understand why X solves to CHI - could somebody please explain?

The names and trivia in other places I got from crosses - I'm hopeless with both Disney and Shakespearean characters. Funny, eh? Not familiar enough with high-brow culture to know Shakespeare, but also clueless about pop-culture's Disney - that's me 🤣. 

About ONION RINGS - I love them even if these days I eat them very rarely for health reasons. They were one of the many things to arrive in Poland with market economy and democracy - before our only deep fried side were plain potato fries. As a kid in the 80s I just loved the typical lunch on a seaside vacation: flounder and fries, served on a paper tray. Onion rings came 10 years later.

Timon is a meerkat first seen in Disney's 1994 animated film The Lion King voiced by Nathan Lane. Here he is with his buddy, the warthog Pumbaa, voiced by another Broadway great, Ernie Sabella, singing Hakuna Matata. https://youtu.be/mzABW42AIhM?si=GJi83aAoCSrkkao_

Testing if I am able to post anything. I tried to comment but each time something strange happened: the formatting of my message was lost, and the notification of the post awaiting moderation looked different than I remember it. Also, I can only see 55 commnets even though the circle on topmof the blog days there are 58. There is a chance three copies of my long comment suddenly appear.
I done did this puzz

Per Deb, I absolutely admired 24D.  I thought it in the moment, and I’m glad to see I wasn’t alone.  There have been myriad great clues over the handful of years I’ve been doing the NYT Crossword (about 7 maybe?), but this one stands out as one of my favourites.

I had to get out of bed due to a fit of rhinitis, and there it was:  Robyn’s name, I knew this would be good. It was one of my fastest Fridays despite continually stopping to sneeze and using 1/2 a box of Kleenex.  HaHa, I thought 24 down was out of my wheelhouse, never getting physics, but laughed when it filled itself in from crosses.  The mahjong answer also needed crosses but got me smiling as a dear friend has taken it up at age 84.  Thanks, Robyn, this puzzle is a favorite gift.
Did anyone else have a problem seeing the puzzle in the Games app ?  The Friday puzzle usually shows up at 7pm PT on Thursday.  Not today  - hopefully this is not a new feature of the app.
Once again, thank you Robyn, it was delightful! <3

How lucky am I to hit my 1,000 no-lookup streak on a Robyn Weintraub puzzle? And it was a gorgeous spring day today. Even the doggo was chill while getting his nails clipped and his locks shorn. The weekend is looking good for putting in tomatoes, too. Ahhhh.

Sigh—a fabulous Robyn Weintraub Friday—what could be better?? Still remember her Friday, October 5, 2018 puzzle with total fondness. Just learning to do the puzzle then, and watching it unfold was a delight.

If this puzzle were a ski run it would be a blue circle…fun, very doable. No diamond or double black diamond here.

tc

I thought this was a tough but fair puzzle.  I don't understand why we are gushing over POD for "SEAL team" in Wordplay when a group of seals isn't a pod at all.  This clue seemed totally misbegotten to me.  

I might have felt done dirty by the ARIEL/TIMON pair if not for the clever pair of clues. I mean, is it actually the same name if it is pronounced two different ways?  

I am also not sure why we are supposed to see Phoenician letters and associate to their Greek equivalents (a recurring theme in the NYT puzzle).  Like, would we be cool with it if the answer were KHA after the Cyrillic letter that also looks like an X?
Starting of with a “for sure” at 1 across was fun for a Friday, and like so many it was great to see Robyn's name as well.

Great puzzle.

The proper noun crossing AVERY and LEVI aside, this was a good Friday. And I especially liked the clue for ONION RINGS.

9/10.
Thank you Robyn. I don’t know if you’re the best, but you’re certainly my favorite!

Had HowCanIRefuse for the longest time, which made solving the NW corner impossible.   I finally realized I could replace reFUsE  with reSIsT, and then the NW came together for me.   Nice trap that I feel into. 😃
Any Robyn Weintraub Friday is a happy Friday! Loved the puzzle

As your resident alphadoppeltotter, a role I’ve inexplicably taken in the past eight years, it is my duty to inform you that this puzzle has an unusually low number of double letters, at four, where unusual is any number less than five. This is the second time this year that this has happened. 

I remain your humble servant, ever on the alert.

There's a fly in my soup!

It didn't go as expected, 

I KEPT the poke bowl a bit too long.
He who noshes on AKI tuna must wait.
The happy music was held up as the grid was scoured - coulda used a sea scallop to help fly speck.

Well then, What a thrilla of filla!
No flies on Robyn Weintraub, that's for sure.

I knew I'd enjoy this one as soon as I saw who constructed it. Typical long Friday workout for me, but very enjoyable with a lot of nice 'aha' moments as I worked things out from the crosses. Six debut answers in this one and almost all of them quite familiar terms - HOWCANIRESIST, YOUGETTHEIDEA, ASEXPECTED, and others. That's just amazing. And of course my puzzle find today. A Sunday from September 9, 2007 by Patrick Berry with the title: "Process of elimination." Can't even describe this one. Here's the 'reveal' clue and answer: "The Process of Elimination: In the answer to each starred clue, cross out any letter that appears ___; then read the letters that remain :" TWICE Never seen another like that. Here's the Xword Info link" https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/9/2007&g=108&d=A I'm done. ....

Oh, that Weintraub brain.  Let me just give three examples:
•	POD has been in the major crossword puzzles more than 300 times, almost always clued boringly.  But today we get to be delighted with [Seal team?].
•	Ditto RAVEN (appearing more than 100 times), but today – [Literary bird with a one-word vocabulary, apparently].  Are you kidding me?  Every thumb up!
•	And the less ubiquitous CEMENT MIXER but OMG clue [Concrete example of rotational forces and fluid dynamics?].

Doth we not feel like royalty to be treated like this?

This keen wit may hide the skill beneath it, a grid so cleanly filled that my whole body relaxes when I look at it.  A grid saturated with beauty as well, for example – AS EXPECTED, HOW CAN I RESIST, NOSHES ON, TRAGIC HERO, YOU GET THE IDEA.  Oh, did I mention that these five answers have never appeared in the Times puzzle before?

Wit, craft, freshness, beauty – artistry in the box.  Spectacular Friday.  You’ve amazingly done it again, Robyn. I am so grateful that your path crossed with Crosslandia’s!

Well, THEN…

A Weintraub Friday.
A Freintraub.

A Weinday.
But I’m not whining. I’m no CRAB.

I really wanted to SIP, savor and 
HONOR the art before me, but
AS EXPECTED, I started slow, 
but after MINIMAL confusion,
and a moment to
THINK IT OVER,
I SAILed through as each entry
OPENed three more, 
which opened five more, 
which…YOU GET THE IDEA.

RIVETing.

Happy Friday all!
lots of fun

Alternate clue for 9D:

Has Robyn Weintraub been pulled from today’s puzzle by an app glitch?

NOSHESON

(A fun one, quick witted.)

I don’t think that a question mark was needed for a walk in the park. That just made it more obscure than needed. I started thinking about baseball. 

Other than that it was delightful.
I found this one really easy and completed it much more quickly than a usual Friday. It felt more like a Tuesday or Wednesday level of difficulty.

Something over sixty years ago, when I first played mahjong, the suits were named, in the slightly awkward translation of the rules,  as being Circles, Characters, and, b Bamboos. Out family names for the latter two were squiggles and sticks. Today was the first time I’ve seen the names in today’s puzzle.

Who among us doesn't smile when we see the Robyn Weintraub byline on a Friday NYT puzzle?

I wasn't forced to take physics in high school. So I didn't. My first glance at the clue filled me with dread. For a couple of seconds. And then CEMENT MIXER made me howl with laughter. 

ONION RINGS have sadly been on my no-no list for a very long time. But when I finally filled in that answer, I swear I was able to conjure up the taste of them, and also the memory of those fabulous Brooklyn Greek diners where I ate too many of them. 

As many of you know that I'm usually cranky and tough to please as of late. Not tonight. Loved it. Thank you, Robyn!

Spent a solid hour on this one on a plane ride but couldn’t quite crack it without checking - had one big error (HOWCANIrefuse at 25A) and that ruined chances of figuring out 9D (didn’t help that intersecting 22D and 30A were not names I knew!) 

Still, a very enjoyable grid - loved PIGEONHOLE as an entry and the clue for CLONES was clever!
Read somewhere that “Here’s looking at you, kid” from 33D is a reference to poker, where the much-sought-after high cards — the “face” cards — are the ones “looking” at you. Can anyone confirm?

It's weird to see [Every month has one] in the singular, since "ides"--a single day--was grammatically plural, in Latin, English, and to titular Shakespearean tragic heros: "The Ides of March are come"/ "Ay, Caesar, but not gone." The Roman Republican calendar was, to our minds, an incredibly complex an illogical system, the calculation of which is best left to the *servi Flaminum*, or their modern descendants, computer AI servers. By one such on-line calculator, which appears to account for the shift from Republican to Julian to Gregorian year counts, today's date is: a.d. XIII Kal. Mai. MMDCCLXXVIII A.U.C. Which translates to "thirteenth day before the Kalends of May, 2778 [years] from the founding of the City" ("Which city?" "Like there is any other!") So (once again, accounting for that calendar shift), although today would fall just past the mid-point (the Ides) of April, it's still referenced in terms of the beginning of May. Also, we would call it "twelve days before . . .", but the Romans counted "inclusively" so those Kalends were included in the count: "thirteen days." Similarly, the Romans had an eight-day "nundial" ("nine days") week. But they named the days A-H, so there's that. https://planetcalc.com/8496/ Felix dies Veneris Veintraubiensis!

What a treat! I saw Robyn's name and eagerly anticipated a lot of smooth sailing. Then I found myself with a lot of unfilled puzzle after the first pass. I shouldn't have worried, though, as ONIONRINGS and CLONES delivered delight the puzzle really popped into life. Indeed the whole thing came together beautifully. I didn't know all the answers, but was able to learn a few things through clever crossword construction without any lookups. Wonderful!

Beautiful puzzle.

Thought the NE might defeat me as I had OWED for OPEN, but kept coming back to it and eventually it gave way.

And "Sides of circles?" 👏👏👏
Is this the same Gary Larson who makes the Far Side comics?

High school physics: Tried to demonstrate that wave theory is constant using jello..... A CEMENTMIXER may have been a better choice.

Suffice to say there was a bit of back and forth on this puzzle.

Thank you Robyn
AS EXPECTED, great fun.  Many thanks.
29.24 on a Friday? Including a break to make coffee? 'Sup? Oh, btw I think a SEAL team would be sailors. Just sayin. Ms. Weintraub is a treasure!
LOVE a Robyn Weintraub puzzle but today's offered no resistance for a Friday. Onion Rings was fun though!

Strands #425
“What a trill!”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵🔵

After an impenetrable set of puzzles at the beginning of the week, yesterday and today were startlingly easy for me. 

PLEASE no spoilers until after there's a View All Replies button.
Nice! Wonderful puzzle. Two great ones in a row!
Didn’t think it would be when I started it, but it turned out to be pretty easy for a Friday.

What is a "TRAGIC HERO"?

Aristotle's definition (which I offer from memory, so the details may be off):
A noble character (noble both of birth and of character) who exhibits a sudden downfall of fortune, due to some "hamartia" of character, eliciting a catharsis of pity and fear from the spectators.
"Hamartia" is often translated as "tragic flaw", but "lack" may be more accurate.

Are Hamlet and Gatsby examples of this?  Neither is without fault, but that is not part of the definition.  In fact, a tragic hero must possess a flaw, cannot be perfect of character (or else, according to Aristotle, their downfall is absurd rather than tragic).
I'd say "Yes" to both.  Although it's interesting to note that Gatsby's "nobility" is not of birth, but is put on (much like his beautiful shirts), but his "social mobility" and his dreams of success are what make him peculiarly American.

So ends today's lecture.  Tomorrow we will discuss...
What a smooth, great puzzle. Thank you, Robyn!

I didn't find it that easy - I didn't even try  to solve 24D, the CEMENT MIXER, I just revealed it. 
Lots of great clues, the circles obviously, HONORS, and all the literary mentions, and isn't LURKS a lovely word?

But I'm not familiar with poke bowls, or the super monkey, or the YADA expression. 
NYT crosswords do favour the Greek alphabet, I wonder why? And don't know 'Evita' so it was a mixed bag.
TIMON again Robyn delivers ARIEL winner.

Yet another Weintraubian Triumph!  (AS EXPECTED when you see that byline, nothing to CRAB about--the crosses will save you from the weird stuff like Monkey Ball and Malaysia --or malaise.)

Completed with CELERity.  
Hah

Late puzzle find - inspired by an old favorite joke popping into my head. Much to my surprise it was actually an answer in one puzzle - a Sunday from January 25, 1981 by Maura B. Jacobson with the title: "Crazy Rhythms." The clue and answer that led me there: "Mathematician's song?" ILOVEMYWIFEBUTOHEUCLID And a couple of others: "Author's song?" ALCOTTSCHILLUNGOTRHYTHM "Jazzman's song?" EUBIESONICETOCOMEHOMETO And there were more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=1/25/1981&g=40&d=A ...

I’m a big Robyn fan and love solving her puzzles. Thanks for another fun one today! But to pick a nit: the mixer is actually mixing concrete, of which cement is an ingredient (the others being sand, gravel, and water). It’s the “glue” that binds the other ingredients to form a strong structure. Sidewalks (pavements), buildings, and roads are often made of concrete. See https://mcconnellassociates.org/what-is-the-difference-between-concrete-and-cement/#:~:text=Cement%20is%20a%20binding%20agent,aluminum%2C%20calcium%2C%20and%20silica for a good discussion. Mark

I wondered briefly if Loni Andersen had starred in a remake of "Hello, Dolly!" That casting actually makes sense to me. LEVI as a last name, on the other hand...not so much. I was pretty sure of AVERY Fisher, though, because my dad was a Hi-Fi nut.

David Geffen Hall ranks up there with the Mario Cuomo Bridge, in terms of unpardonable offenses.

Breezy for a Friday but so much fun. I was *delighted* by the Disney/Shakespeare clues, and all the better that they were right next to each other. The literary bird was just perfect. Really enjoyable as always, Ms. Weintraub - thanks for your efforts!

As one who generally struggles on Fridays, often an hour, this went by fast, as others have commented. However, that is not the reason I am commenting. This puzzle was so enjoyable, and really the reason I love doing them. Like a work of art. Thanks Robyn.
Great puzzle! Long answers were fluid, not too much in the way of nonsense words. Fantastic

Today's ear worm: Hello Dolly!

This is a tough one because the song is so long, and, as an ear worm, it's hard to get rid of. According to a recent article, however (in the Times, I believe), a short ditty like "My Country Tis of Thee" will kill the ear worm. Today may be the day to try that out!

As for the puzzle itself, that was a fun ride! It took me a minute to realize there was no theme...I forgot it was Friday! But since it is...I must get off my but and get ready for my shift at the ER. Have a great Friday everyone, and see ya tomorrow!
Too easy for a Friday! I like just a little morning torture at the end of the week.

Well, I tried not to race through this one, but I couldn't help it. This puzzle was a joy while it lasted, but it didn't last long. I loved ONION RINGS and CEMENT MIXER, and even the OREO clue was fresh - but now what an I supposed to do with the rest of my Friday morning? Zip! Boom! Bang! Thanks for the fun!

Today’s Easy Mode newsletter is interesting, though many of us already know much of this:

How puzzle editors create the difficulty curve

By Christina Iverson
 
“How do the creators of crosswords make them harder as the week goes on?” — Quentin Berry

From Christina:

There are a few things constructors consider when thinking about the difficulty level of a puzzle. When making a Monday or Tuesday puzzle, the theme should be relatively straightforward and simple, and shouldn’t leave solvers scratching their heads. It’s OK, though, for solvers on a Wednesday or a Thursday to have to think a bit before they understand the theme. Along with a simple theme, a constructor making a Monday grid will likely use a grid with a higher word count.

Our maximum word count for themed puzzles is 78 words, and the maximum for a themeless puzzle (Friday or Saturday) is 72 words. The number of words in a grid pretty directly correlates with how difficult the vocabulary in the grid is. A grid with more words (which will be shorter on average) tends to be easier to fill with easier vocabulary that’s more “Monday-friendly.” A 72-word themeless puzzle will likely have easier vocabulary than a 66-word themeless puzzle, which is more likely to be placed on a Saturday. The average Monday puzzle has 76.9 words, compared with 74.6 words on a Thursday, and 68.7 words on a Saturday. A Monday puzzle also tends to have quite a few more black squares — 37.5, compared with 30.9 on a Saturday.

[more]
Wonderful puzzle, thanks! Favorite clue/answer pair: ONION RINGS. CEMENT MIXER a close second.
Make these ‘easy Friday’ puzzles PRINTABLE. Sorry Gen whatever, but many of us don’t want - and don’t like - to solve on line or in an app. We prefer paper and pencil.
Annnnd a blessed Robyn Weintraub Friday to you, Deb! 😌

Wow! Just solved Robyn's masterpiece in easy mode - SIX minute solve. Took 28 mins. off my first tussle. (Yup, 'done did dat' ala Eddie, but the clues shed a new, slightly dimmer light on the process. After watching 2025 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, realized clues can transform the solving ship from a dinghy into an ocean liner - 24D ( As offered to Friday maistream solvers) "Concrete example of rotational forces and fluid dynamics?" (easy mode) "Truck seen on a construction site when a foundation is being poured" It's worth a go: https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/paid/easy-mode-97 You can subscribe to easymode, or find all the grids with training wheels at https://www.nytimes.com/search?query=Easy+mode+puzzle Happy Weekend, y'all.
A common phenomenon for me (as was the case yesterday and today): bombing badly on the Thursday puzzle and then breezing through the Friday puzzle. Anyone else observed the same thing?
There appears to be an error at 39D/58A. The crossing should be the D of LETSEND with the S of SEND. What gives?
Disney and Shakespeare are two of my crossword and trivia Achilles heels. Dastardly to combine them! The puzzle was overall great though

I don’t know if there will be a 2025 Puzzle of the Year “contest” (for lack of a better word), but just in case there is, I’m keeping a running list of candidates. 

Today’s fun puzzle is the first themeless puzzle on my list. 

Thanks, Ms Weintraub!

I take umbrage with ‘lurks’ meaning ‘just watching without saying a word’. I’ve always considered ‘lurk’ to have a more nefarious meaning.  Would you say that someone watching a baseball game quietly is ‘lurking’ in the stands? Probably not. A burglar sitting in their car outside your house at night is ‘lurking’.

Everybody but me seems to have found this easy. For me it was an hour plus of looking up things like "dolly," "shakespeare timo," "igor si," etc., etc.

I even had to look up "malaysia." In spite of attending a conference there for three days in the 1990's, __NA__ refused to shout "Penang" at me.
So much fun, and my best time ever on a Friday!  HOW CAN I RESIST ONION RINGS?
A new personal best, and great fun to boot. Thanks!
Themeless Wednesday. Too easy (for me) to really enjoy. Call me a CRAB.
I'm going to guess that Eddie gun dun this puzz.

Are we just going to ignore the caption?

Prince William offering a bowl of water to an odd-looking, orange dog in a lab.
Credit...Oli Scarff/Pool, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
Don’t get me wrong, I enjoyed the puzzle, but it felt really easy for a Friday. I must have been on just the right wavelength, because I set a new best at around my average Tuesday time.
Enjoyed the Friday crossword but take issue with 31 across. It should be CHE not CHI. Am I missing something here?

As a longtime NYT crossword fan, daughter #1 thoughtfully gifted me the app for Christmas— and it’s become a real problem. Since there’s always an archive puzzle to do when I’ve “got a minute”, the Stats tell me I’ve now done 421. And by doing all those puzzles, they get easier and easier (because now I know answers like “NOOB”, and”ANYA” Taylor-Joy). Puzzles that used to take me literally days to wrestle through (which I loved) are now over in under 20 minutes— far too soon!  Can anybody relate?
This was an excellent Friday, had to take several breaks for brain rest but with persistence I got the gold star which is exactly what these type of puzzles should be like imo

Saw a few “too easy” comments, but for me it was just about right. Did some at breakfast time, and the rest after my morning hike. It was just crunchy enough for my taste, so thanks, Robyn, for another one of your sparkling puzzles. Not knowing anything about Mahjong, and also missing the misdirection behind “Sunfish feature” that crossing of 36A and 36D was my final spot to fill. Thanks to the whole team for a sparkling Friday puzzle.

Looks like I'm the odd one out today! I had a weirdly tough time with this one. I think Robyn Weintraub and I have very different brains. To be clear, I enjoy her puzzles, I just think I have a disproportionately tough time of them. I loved a lot of the cluing today, especially CEMENT MIXER and ONION RING, which were among the few that I got on a first pass. For some reason I just struggle with Weintraub's clues for plainer fill, like CRAB, LURKS, PITA, FOB etc.. 

Anyway, always fun to come to the comments and see the people who had the opposite experience to yours. It hit me at just the right time, too -- I've had some really easy solves in the past week, setting new personal bests on both Sunday (16:08) and Wednesday (5:46) -- if it hadn't been for this I might have started to get pretty full of myself.

My brother-in-law who works in the industry says the REALLY correct term for that mixer is "Aggregate transporter" but his company has T-shirts saying "Concrete kicks asphalt" (he got one for us) so as long as one eschews "cement" one is probably ok

Robyn Weintraub’s in da house!

That’s all I’ve got. It’s a good day, this. 

Capping off a day graced by a Robynian Weintraubian creation is the fact that my husband’s flight will be landing soon after his being gone 7 (!) weeks plus 1 day. It’s really that last 1 day that was the hardest to take, due as it was solely to rotational forces and fluid dynamics Texas style: tornadoes. I had already told Señor Gato that, come Thursday, the brusher-in-chief would be back, restoring all order to feline worlds, including—though not limited to—the random singing of nonsensical songs about one Señor Gato, an overabundance of energy and constant motion, cat videos on the big TV (because TVs would be plugged into outlets again), and the general happy commotion that is my husband. (I may have also let out a “Yipee! I can go back to not being the litter box-cleaning parent again!” but I digress.)

Then I had to take it all back. (And clean the box myself for one more day.) 

But after being rerouted around the country a few times, my husband finally managed to leave tornadoes behind. Now he can get back to the disasters here in Europe. And right off the bat, there’s the one I put in the fridge after the pizza place delivered it to me yesterday instead of the veggie pizza I’d ordered. This pie is topped by glops of what appears to be cabbage drowned in mayo over Italian sausage. 

I am so, so very too flyover-country for this continent…

Fun puzzle, and, as many others did, I loved ONION RINGS and CEMENT MIXER. (CEMENT MIXER makes me think of James Taylor singing "I'm a CEment mixer.") 

I was glad to see 3D. One of my biggest grammatical pet peeves is people being unable to correctly use lie and lay and their conjugations. In my experience, people often avoid saying (and writing) "I LAID it down." I'm guessing that's because they've heard so many people incorrectly saying "I LAID down" that they've gotten the idea that "laid" is never correct!

Sometimes I come to the comments to seek sympathy for some terrible naticks or awful proper nouns or greek letters which befuddled me.

Other times I come to the comments after a pleasant solve and see how if I'd answered certain things differently, I might have splintered on a reef.

Had it occurred to me that HOWCANIREfuSe was a viable answer for 25A, this puzzle could have gone from fairly easy and straightforward to impossible.

I pretty sure there are different temperaments of crossworders.  Some who are aggressive, and jump right in with the long ones.  And others (like me) who meekly fill in the easy ones, not daring a long one until there are enough crosses to make it as near to foolproof as possible.

I wonder which strategy plays out better in the long run.

Tufffff, but I only had to look up what "fetes" meant. I wanted to do more lookups but managed to puzzle it out. 
PENANG, LEVI, ILSA and the mahjong clue were all new to me! Fun puzzle.
Kinda hated this one. Not good.
Loved the puzzle! Especially since it included PENANG! Who’da thought that would show up? Named after the areca catechu or the PINANG tree. So cool!
29A: The name of the character isn't in the title of the Disney movie. How does that make it titular?

I've been around the Comments for a while, 
so I'm used to comments not appearing 
for one reason or another, or for no reason at all.

What is new to me is getting an email from the Times 
that a comment has been approved and it doesn't appear.  

It *is* shown appearing in the Comments in the link in the email, but it actually is not in the Comments.



You can't make this stuff up.

This comment as a reply in the thread only shows up in the thread when I click on a time stamp in the thread.




HeathieJ,

That's totally insane! Thanks for the tip. I clicked on the time stamp in the Cement Mixer thread, where I'd posted a link to the frozen custard, and lots of replies that had been invisible appeared.
One of the hardest Friday puzzles lately. My worst Friday time.
Cancel my last comment. My bad!

Haven't broken a quarter hour all week. Hoping for more length tomorrow! (Actually, if easier ones during the week make more folks feel brave enough to stick with the learning curve, I can live with it.)

This one was still fun. The only thing new I learned was the Malaysian state. But that was made up for because I had one good laugh-out-loud, at the physics clue. Not only because rotational forces are in my wheelhouse, but because one of these items has been on my street waking me up recently. I go outside each day to see how much more of that rotating fluid they are likely to pour into the new condo construction across the street.
The problem with most restaurants that serve them is, they're all batter and no onion.

So proud today! My first Friday with no look-ups and a best time for me! Loved the breezy wordplay as well! I also learned that there were once Uh-oh Oreos! (Although my first thought was Spaghetti-Os, but that was too long!)

this one took a bit, definitely needed some lookups. it was a fun puzzle, but boy am i tired. it seems like more and more im left with more questions than i have answers at the end of the solve. 

maybe i should LURK less and let my SAILS take some wind and see where it SENDS me?? who knows anymore 😅

@Joe Felice Terima kasih (thank you, in Malay) for knowing the word AMOK and the beautiful island of PENANG. Wanted to clarify that “Malaysian” refers to the country of Malaysia with its diverse (multi-ethnic) population while “Malay” refers to the rich language and culture of the Malay people who are based across several Southeast Asian countries (and beyond). Hence AMOK is a Malay word while PENANG is a Malaysian island (and state).

@john ezra

It's been many years since I read The Great Gatsby, but I recognized the source from the first sentence sentence immediately.

Do you remember, "They were careless people, Tom and Daisy . . . "?  So many times I have met/known people who personified that carelessness.  

I've seen some comments questioning Gatsby's status as a TRAGIC HERO—of course he was.  So was Fitzgerald, who gave Gatsby rich details from his own life and stepped by\back into Nick, the dispassionate observer of the story.

I have never seen a movie that was able to catch the pervading madness of that time and place as Fitzgerald wrote it.

@Barry Ancona

In Polish the name is "betoniarka". Beton means concrete, and cement is... Cement. So we actually call the machine a concrete mixer, albeit in Polish 🤷🏾

@Barry Ancona

I wasn’t complaining about the clue, nor was I criticising the constructor.  I was just pointing out that the device is not really a CEMENT MIXER though I concede that many if not most folks call it that, just as they call its output cement, which it is not.

The rest of Christina’s answer:

The “freshness” of the vocabulary in a grid can also make a big difference in how difficult the puzzle is. Constructors of a Monday puzzle will intentionally use familiar vocabulary. While they would like the longer entries in the grid to be fun, it’s less common for such answers to be ultrafresh terms or phrases that have never been in a crossword before. In a later-week puzzle, though, constructors will go out of their way to include more crunchy entries that might be considered too hard on a Monday.

The end of Christine’s answer:

The final piece of the puzzle is the difficulty of the clues. Even if the vocabulary in a Saturday puzzle is fairly familiar, constructors can always beef up a puzzle with tricky wordplay and trivia. If there is some tough vocabulary that sneaked its way into a Monday puzzle, everything else in that area can be given really easy clues to ensure that solvers can succeed.

@Glenn Weinberg Yes I raced to within 6 squares of finishing in 22 minutes, and my Friday average time is around 55 minutes. I then had to fix an error that caused the puzzle to take me 29 minutes total, but that’s just over half my normal Friday time and probably a personal record.

@Joe P  Yes. Then I went back deep into the archives and had a very different experience. They were significantly harder in the 90s, for example. So if it turns out you and I are immortal, there will be plenty of puzzles to keep us busy.
@Jake  Hahaha— I was just working backwards (now in November 2023). I’ll try “going deep”!

@Joe P

I certainly can relate to the growth in puzzle ability.  I went from 3+ hours on the weekends to usually under an hour.

I suppose everyone is a little like this, but it seems to that I am enormously helped by a single cross letter.  An answer can be completely escaping me, but if I get a single letter, especially the first or the last (for a non-plural) I'm much, much more likely to come up with the answer.  It's like I need a little grounding.

And that being the case, then knowing and quickly entering even few crosswordese words like ONO and OREO and AVOW and AVER, which I didn't know at the start, gives me a lot of letters to work with on the harder ones.

Anyhow, if I feel fairly good about an answer, including a long one, I'll try it out. Over time, I've gotten a lot better at being willing to rip it out if I can't get crosses.... Just like when I was saying WINBYAhair instead of NOSE the first part of the phrase was clearly justified by the crosses, but when I couldn't get crosses for hair, I just took it out. 

That willingness to plop it in but accept my potential wrongness has really been the game changer for me.
